sentences: John Charles Thomas (September 6, 1891 – December 13, 1960) was an American opera, operetta and concert baritone.
John Charles Thomas was born on September 6, 1891 in Meyersdale, Pennsylvania.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: After studying initially for a medical career, Thomas won a scholarship to the Peabody Institute in Baltimore in 1910.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He remained there for two years, receiving vocal tuition from Adelin Fermin.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: In 1912, Thomas left the Peabody and toured briefly with a musical troupe.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: He then went to live in Manhattan, New York City, where he performed with a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta company before being contracted by the Shubert brothers to perform in the show The Peasant Girl, which opened in March 1913.
section: == Biography ==

sentences: For the next nine years, he starred in a series of hit Broadway musicals including Her Soldier Boy, Maytime, Naughty Marietta, and Apple Blossoms (with Fred and Adele Astaire).
section: == Biography ==

sentences: Thomas sang in a concert performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's opera Sadko at Manhattan's Carnegie Hall in December 1924.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: His debut in a fully staged opera occurred in March 1925, as Amonasro in a production of Verdi's Aida, presented by the semi-professional Washington National Opera.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: During the 1922-28 period, he spent part of each year in Europe, polishing his singing technique and appearing under contract at La Monnaie opera house in Brussels for the seasons of 1925-27.

sentences: Even more importantly, he appeared with the famous Russian bass Feodor Chaliapin in productions of Faust at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, in July 1928.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He continued to give recitals in the United States during this period and, in 1923, acted in a silent film, Under the Red Robe, directed by Alan Crosland.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He made recordings, too, for the Vocalion label (1920–24) and Brunswick Records (1924–29), before signing with RCA Victor in 1931.

sentences: From 1929-32 he was a member of the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company, and in 1930 made one appearance with the Philadelphia Civic Opera Company.

section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He accepted engagements with the Washington National, San Francisco, Chicago and Philadelphia opera companies, and in 1934, to satisfy a public demand, he was signed by the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He would remain at the Met until 1943, performing opposite such stars as the soprano Rosa Ponselle.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: In the tough Great Depression years of the 1930s, he established himself as one of the most sought-after singers in America, with both a classical-music following and a considerable popular audience.

sentences: In 1938, he helped Edwin Lester launch the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera, appearing in the company's very first production in Blossom Time.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: Thomas sang regularly in operettas with the LACLO until 1942, starring in productions of The Gypsy Baron, H.M.S. Pinafore, The Chocolate Soldier and Music in the Air.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: Thomas was duly engaged to star on the Westinghouse Radio Program in 1943-46, accompanied by the Victor Young Orchestra.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He probably reached his widest audience during this period, although his practice of performing songs exclusively in English has perhaps left him less well-remembered by today's musical "purists" than he should be.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: Thomas was among the founders of the Music Academy of the West summer conservatory in 1947.

section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: From 1947 to 1948, Thomas undertook a long and demanding tour of Australia and New Zealand, where he played to crowded theatres.
section: == Biography == | === Operatic, recital and radio career ===

sentences: He retired bit by bit from the concert stage after 1950, and settled in Apple Valley, California in 1955 with his wife Dorothy.

sentences: John Charles Thomas left a large pool of audio recordings, many of which sold extremely well in their day and have been transferred in recent times to compact disc.
section: == Recordings ==

sentences: Thomas belonged to a sequence of leading American operatic baritones whose overlapping careers stretched in an unbroken line from the 1920s through to the 1990s.
section: == Voice ==

sentences: Thomas belonged to a sequence of leading American operatic baritones whose overlapping careers stretched in an unbroken line from the 1920s through to the 1990s.
section: == Voice ==

sentences: By 1931, and certainly by 1934, he had found the more fluid, natural vocal style for which he is best remembered.
section: == Voice ==

section: == Voice ==

sentences: From the late 1940s into the '50s, his vibrato began to widen, though it never became an unpardonable flaw in his singing technique, and the voice grew somewhat thicker and heavier in tone.
